conclusion: Determine the acceleration of the cargo A when it is first placed on the conveyor and find the time it takes for the cargo to travel from the left end to the right end.
Cargo A is at rest when first placed on the conveyor, which moves with constant speed v0 = 2 m/s.
The only force acting on the cargo in the horizontal direction is the kinetic friction force due to the conveyor belt.
The kinetic friction force fk is given by fk = mu1 N, where mu1 is the kinetic friction coefficient and N is the normal force.
Since the cargo is on a horizontal surface, the normal force N is equal to the weight of the cargo mg, thus N = mg.
The kinetic friction force is fk = mu1 mg.
The acceleration a of the cargo due to this friction force is given by Newton's second law: a = fk/m = mu1 g.
Substituting the given values, a = 0.2 x 10 = 2 m/s^2.
The acceleration of the cargo A when it is just placed on the conveyor is 2 m/s^2.
Consider two phases of motion: the phase where the cargo accelerates to the speed of the conveyor and the phase where the cargo moves at a constant speed.
Phase 1: The cargo accelerates from rest to the speed of the conveyor v0 = 2 m/s with an acceleration a = 2 m/s^2.
The time t1 taken to reach the speed v0 is t1 = v0/a = 2/2 = 1 s.
The distance d1 traveled during this acceleration phase is d1 = 1/2 a t1^2 = 1/2 x 2 x 1^2 = 1 m.
Phase 2: After reaching the speed v0, the cargo moves at a constant speed v0 = 2 m/s.
The remaining distance d2 to be traveled is d2 = L1 - d1 = 6 - 1 = 5 m.
The time t2 taken to travel this distance at a constant speed is t2 = d2/v0 = 5/2 = 2.5 s.
The total time t taken to travel from the left end to the right end is t = t1 + t2 = 1 + 2.5 = 3.5 s.
The time it takes for the cargo to travel from the left end to the right end is 3.5 s.
